channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: London Perl and Raku Workshop
item.description: October 26, 2024, in London, UK

item.title: Toronto Perl Mongers monthly meeting
item.description: July 25, 2024, Virtual event

item.title: Continuous Integration (CI): GitHub Actions for Perl Projects
item.description: August 4, 2024, in Zoom

item.title: Purdue Perl Mongers
item.description: July 10, 2024, Virtual event

item.title: Boston.pm monthly meeting
item.description: July 9, 2024, Virtual event

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description: Great CPAN modules released last week.

item.title: Complete frequency
item.description: For me, it is the source of Python magics. Thanks for introducting Counters function. Thanks for your contributions.

item.title: Maximum Frequency and now my Day is Complete
item.description: Welcome back to blogging and thanks for introduction to Python. It is always pleasure to have your post. Thank you.

item.title: Frequency Day is Complete
item.description: Lua is the pick of the language this week. I really enjoy the varieties each week. Highly recommended.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #276
item.description: Clever use of CPAN modules is very handy. Happy to see the wide use of the modules. Keep sharing the knowledge.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 276
item.description: As always, we see the use of CPAN modules again. All heavy lifting done by the modules, rest is just a thin layer on top. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Round days and frequent numbers
item.description: I noticed the use of v5.26 and few other bits. I am sure it would work with the latest release too (v5.40). Well done.

item.title: Complete Maximum Day Frequency
item.description: Smart use of CPAN module makes the code short and easy to follow. Great work, keep it up.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 276
item.description: Unique hack used in this week's Perl solution. Well done.

item.title: filtering arrays
item.description: Raku one-liner is showing method chaining and giving us effective solution. Thanks for your contributions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 276: Maximum Frequency
item.description: Method chaining of Raku makes the code compact and elegant. Raku Rocks !!!

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 276: Complete Day
item.description: Building combinations function of Raku in Perl can be so easy and simple. Thanks for sharing knowledge with us.

item.title: Hourly Frequencies
item.description: PDL once again showing the cool features. The end result is not be missed. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Complete Maximum
item.description: Power of Raku made the difficult task easy and at times allow to create elegant one-liner. Thanks for contributing.

item.title: Completed and Maximum Frequency Days
item.description: Check out the comparison of Prolog, C and Perl. The analysis is worth reading.

item.title: TWC276
item.description: Compact yet powerful solutions in Perl shared in the post. Well done.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 276
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Complete Day" and "Maximum Frequency" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 277
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Count Common" and "Strong Pair". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: GitHub Pages for Perl developers (Free Virtual presentation on August 15)
item.description: In this virtual event you will learn how to use Markdown and GitHub Pages to create a simple web site and then we'll extend our use of GitHub Actions to generate the site using Perl. Register now!

item.title: Continuous Integration (CI): GitHub Actions for Perl Projects (Free Virtual presentation on August 4)
item.description: This events was postponed to August 4. In this virtual event you will learn why and how to use GitHub Actions as a CI system for your Perl projects. The meeting is free of charge thanks to my supporters via Patreon and GitHub. Besides this event I am running many more, so make sure you check the Code Mavens meetup group and also register to it.

item.title: New Standards of Conduct published
item.description: TPRF has created a new Standard of Conduct to help combat bullying, harassment and abuse in our communities.

item.title: Perl v5.40.0 Shows That It Is Too Resilient To Die
item.description: If you missed the latest release Perl v5.40 then you must checkout this to find out more about the core enhancements in the latest release.

item.title: Combining calendars
item.description: Get to know the story behind the CPAN module: App::Mergecal.

item.title: An OpenAI Chatbot in Perl
item.description: Find out how to use the latest core OOP syntax to create OpenAPI Chatbot.

item.title: #676 - Perl and OpenAI
item.description:
hi there,

I am not qualified to give my opinion on OpenAPI. I have noticed Curtis has an opinion and widely respected too. If you haven't read then I would highly recommend you please do, e.g. Will You Loose Your Job to AI?, Claude Sonnet 3.5 beats ChatGPT 4.0 and Building an iPhone App with ChatGPT.

How about Perl dealing with the OpenAI? We have another post, An OpenAI Chatbot in Perl, where you will find the detailed discussion on how you can use the core OOP with OpenAI. Talking about Corinna, we are aware the progress is slow and steady. Having said, there is still plenty of work needed to be done. There is a dicussion on How you can help get Corinna in the core faster? on reddit. Feel free to share your views and if possible offer your help to speed up the work.

With the recent release of Perl v5.40, you can find out the details of core ehancements in Perl v5.40.0 Shows That It Is Too Resilient To Die and What's New in Perl v5.40?.

Dave Cross released a new CPAN module App::MergeCal and shared his story behind it in the post: Combining calendars.

Enjoy rest of the newsletter and please look after yourself.
item.dc:subject: editorial
